home.nostr_intro: Nostr is like a worldwide messaging system where anyone can participate. You can share messages and information with others, and here's what's special about it: it doesn't belong to anyone but works through a network of connected computers (relays).
home.protocol_basics_intro: In Nostr, everything that happens is a message (event). Whether you post something, follow someone, or change your profile - everything is sent as a message with a specific format.

event_structure.title: Message Structure
event_structure.id_desc: A unique number for each message (like a fingerprint)
event_structure.pubkey_desc: Your public key (like your digital signature)
event_structure.kind_desc: What type of message it is (e.g., text, profile change)
event_structure.content_desc: The actual content of your message
event_structure.sig_desc: Your digital signature that proves the message is from you

protocol_concepts.title: Important Basic Terms
protocol_concepts.nips_vs_kinds_explanation: NIPs are like building instructions for Nostr, and message types tell us what kind of message it is:

nips_section.title: What are NIPs?
nips_section.intro: NIPs are like building instructions for Nostr. They explain how different parts of Nostr should work so all apps can talk to each other.
nips_section.docs: NIPs are documents with instructions for Nostr. They suggest new features, improve existing ones, or show the best way to implement something.
nips_section.website: Here you'll find simple explanations and examples of the different NIPs to help you better understand how Nostr works.

explanation.title: NIPs (Nostr Building Instructions)
points: How new features should be built into Nostr
What rules all apps must follow
How information should be passed along correctly
How apps talk to each other
explanation.example: For example, NIP-01 is like the basic rulebook, and NIP-02 explains how contact lists work.

event_kinds.title: Message Types
event_kinds.explanation_intro: Every message in Nostr has a number that tells us what kind of message it is. This number determines:
purpose_points: What's in the message (text, image, etc.)
How apps should display the message
How long the message is stored
event_kinds.connection_to_nips: The NIPs tell us what each number means. The most important numbers (0-3) were set in the first NIP.

ranges.title: Types of Messages and their Numbers (Kinds)
ranges.regular: Regular messages (Kind 0-999): Your profile, texts, and your contacts
ranges.regular_replaceable: Updatable messages (Kind 1000-9999): Only the latest version matters
ranges.ephemeral: Temporary messages (Kind 10000-19999): These aren't stored permanently

event_kinds.contacts: Who you follow and which relays you use

implementation_example.title: An Example:
implementation_example.content: When a message has the number 1, every app knows: This is a regular text that everyone should be able to read - like a public post.

relays_section.title: What are Relays?
relays_section.intro: Relays are like post offices on the internet. They receive your messages and make sure they reach the right people. Anyone can run such a 'post office', and you can use several of them.

flexible.title: Freely Selectable
flexible.description: You decide which relays to use

clients_section.title: What are Clients?
clients_section.intro: Clients are apps you can use to access Nostr. They help you write and read messages, edit your profile, and stay in touch with others.

web.title: Web Apps
web.description: Easy to use in your browser

summary.title: Summary
summary.text: Nostr is like a big network of post offices (relays) and apps (clients) through which you can communicate with others. The NIPs are like a rulebook that tells everyone how they can participate. This website helps you understand all of this better.
summary.info_box: Explore the different NIPs and learn how you can become part of Nostr.

nip1.key_protocol_description: NIP-01 defines the fundamental concepts and mechanisms of the Nostr protocol. It is the cornerstone for all other NIPs and must be supported by all Nostr implementations.

connection.title: Relay Connection
connection.description: Connection status and control of relay servers

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: NIP-01 establishes the foundational structure for all Nostr communication

items.title: Event Structure
items.description: Standardized format for all Nostr data

points: NIP-01 establishes the basic structure of events
Defines communication between clients and relays
Describes authentication and validation of events
Establishes the publish/subscribe model for data exchange

event_structure.title: Event Structure
event_structure.description: An event is the basic data unit in Nostr. Every action and piece of information is transmitted as an event.

id.title: ID
id.description: A SHA-256 hash of all other event fields. Serves as a unique identifier.
id.technical: Calculated from the serialization of event data (excluding 'id' and 'sig')

pubkey.title: Public Key
pubkey.description: The event author's public key in hexadecimal format.

created_at.title: Creation Timestamp
created_at.description: Unix timestamp of event creation in seconds.
created_at.technical: Must be a valid Unix timestamp

kind.title: Event Kind
kind.description: Numerical value defining the type of event.

tags.title: Tags
tags.description: List of tags for additional metadata and references.

content.title: Content
content.description: The actual content of the event as text.

sig.title: Signature
sig.technical: 64-byte Schnorr signature of the event ID value

relay_communication.title: Relay Communication
relay_communication.description: Communication between clients and relays occurs via WebSocket connections.

subscription.title: Subscription System
subscription.description: Clients can subscribe to events using filters:
filter_options: until: Events up to a timestamp

best_practices.title: Best Practices
client_practices: Connect to multiple relays for redundancy
Local caching of frequently used data
Implement exponential backoff for connection errors
